content.body: https://github.com/eemeli/proposal-intl-currency-display-choices

We don't throw when you mutate a Map while iterating. I'd almost rather `getOrInsertComputed` just overwrites the key, whether it was set or deleted during the callback. If you want full locking, you can implement it yourself?
content.formatted_body: We don't throw when you mutate a Map while iterating. I'd almost rather getOrInsertComputed just overwrites the key, whether it was set or deleted during the callback. If you want full locking, you can implement it yourself?

content.body: rbuckton: that IS my understanding of the non-throwing approach
content.formatted_body: rbuckton: that IS my understanding of the non-throwing approach

content.body: is it not?

content.formatted_body:
the four options:

// common prefix
if (map.has(key)) return key;
let value = callback(key);

// option 1
if (map.has(key)) throw;

// option 2
map.set(key, value);
return value;

// option 3 (not proposed)
if (map.has(key)) return map.get(key);
map.set(key, value);
return value;

// option 4 (not proposed): change `Map.prototype.set` to check if we're currently in a `getOrInsertComputed` for this map

sounds like people

map.set(key, value);
return value;

// option 4 (not proposed): change `Map.prototype.set` to check if we're currently in a `getOrInsertComputed` for this map

sounds like people like option 2 (which I'm also happy with)

the four options:

// common prefix

let value = callback(key);

// option 1

map.set(key, value);
return value;

// option 2
map.set(key, value);
return value;

// option 3 (not proposed)
if (map.has(key)) return map.get(key);

content.body: Regarding the naming, neither of these methods are actually an "upsert", which normally consists of either "updating an existing value" or "inserting a new value", hence the portmanteau of "update" and "insert".

University of Bergen's students have written a tutorial on `upsert` proposal prototype implementations in SpiderMonkey and V8. The current preliminary (rough) draft is available here: https://github.com/bldl/emplace-spidermonkey . It currently lacks the description of the implementation in V8; this will be added soon.
content.formatted_body: University of Bergen's students have written a tutorial on upsert proposal prototype implementations in SpiderMonkey and V8. The current preliminary (rough) draft is available here: https://github.com/bldl/emplace-spidermonkey . It currently lacks the description of the implementation in V8; this will be added soon.

}

I understand; the question is, would it help to make the text more explicit?
i think we've generally considered merging a requirement
but we also don't usually block advancements on procedural things that are unambiguous - we usually grant conditional advancement pending that thing
* but we also don't usually block advancements on procedural things whose completion is unambiguous - we usually grant conditional advancement pending that thing

m.new_content.body: but we also don't usually block advancements on procedural things whose completion is unambiguous - we usually grant conditional advancement pending that thing

content.body: * but we also don't usually block advancements on procedural things whose completion is unambiguous - we usually grant conditional advancement pending that thing (a PR review, a PR merge, etc)

content.body: * but we also don't usually block advancements on procedural things whose completion is unambiguous - we usually grant conditional advancement pending that thing (a PR review, a PR merge, resolving an open question between known stakeholders, etc)
